--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
 
> 
> I'm not sure I agree. Although we give weaker genomes a chance by 
> protecting them in a species, overall, weak genomes and weak 
species 
> will be culled from the population. So if I create a population of 
> random genomes then they will all be in a species of one to begin 
with - 
> and the stronger genomes will progressively take over the 
population 
> based on their relative fitness.
> 

First, I'm not sure why every genome would be a in a species of size 
1?  Wouldn't some of them by chance be in the same species?  This of 
course depends on the compatibility threshold.

More importantly, although it is true that down the line the better 
random topologies will come to dominate, you still end up wasting 
significant time evaluating completely useless random topologies.
Because the population is speciated, you waste even more evaluations 
than you normally would since these poor random topologies will 
persist longer than normal due to fitness sharing.  

The reason starting minimally takes care of this problem is that 
then every topological innovation is tried and tested, leading to 
topologies that have been justified through evaluations and 
therefore *desereve* to be protected a species where they have a 
chance to elaborate.


> >
> > This is a sensible fix, but NEAT for example was designed to 
avoid
> > the need for this kind of ad hoc fitness tinkering. If you start
> > minimally and speciate, the system should tend towards minimality
> > without the need for penalities.
> 
> I think I'm missing something! How do you prevent NEAT 
genomes/networks 
> from growing out of control? After all a network may have 
thousands of 
> neurons but only a couple of them may actually be performing the 
task at 
> hand. Perhaps this is just a consequence of NEAT's speed - it 
doesn't 
> (hasn't had to) evolve long enough to fall into this trap? How 
long do 
> NEAT evolution runs normally last? From what I know so far I can 
only 
> imagine that if we gave NEAT a problem that was too hard to solve 
and 
> left it to evolve for any considerable time then the genomes would 
just 
> keep getting longer - I'm more than happy to be proved wrong 
though :)
> 
> 

Speciation has a more powerful effect than you are imagining.  
Speciation means that with a very hard problem NEAT will *both* keep 
getting more complex *and* stay simple.  That's because the simpler 
species is protected, and therefore will never go extinct as long as 
it is competitive (and in a hard problem where NEAT can't make 
progress, all the species will look about the same: bad).  On the 
other hand, other more complex species will also continue to 
appear.  That's what's so appealing about speciating based on 
topolgoies- it means that NEAT doesn't put all its eggs in one 
basket.  It maintains simple candidates and increasingly complex 
ones at the same time.  Thus, it does not suffer from universal 
bloat.

We have run experiments to demonstrate this property empirically.  
In the experiments, we assigned completely random fitness to all the 
genomes.  Now, you might expect complexity to just keep rising in 
such a situation, but in fact, because of speciation, a very simple 
species persisted throughout the runs, while at the same time 
complexity in other species continued to increase.
